title: High-School Girls Are Leaving the Basketball Court in Droves—or Are They?
text:
Why would 13,000 high-school girls suddenly quit basketball, as the latest High School Athletics Participation Survey suggests happened last year?

The answer is: Maybe they didn’t.

The annual survey is the most comprehensive count of high-school sports participation available, and this year’s headline—picked up by dozens of news outlets around the country—was that for the first time in 30 years, participation was down.

But the overall decrease of 0.5% was slight, and the survey, published by the National Federation of State High School Associations, has several characteristics that suggest the findings should be viewed with caution.

Primarily, the federation writes rulebooks for boys’ and girls’ sports. But its most popular release is the participation survey, which is used to monitor and respond to trends, such as changes in a sport’s popularity.

The federation has compiled the survey in its current form since 1971 using numbers it receives from 50 state high-school associations and the District of Columbia. The reports are voluntary. The instructions for collecting the data are sparse. And the number of schools that respond varies from year to year.

It’s up to the state associations to figure out what to do when schools fail to report, and some fill in the gaps with estimates.

That’s true for Texas, California, Ohio and Illinois, four of the Top 5 states with the largest numbers of high-school sports participants. New York, the remaining state in the group, doesn’t use estimates.

“We see weird stuff from year to year, and we have to call a state and ask what’s up,” said Bruce Howard, the federation’s director of publications and communications. “This year, it was Texas girls’ basketball.”

According to the survey, which was released earlier this month, participation in girls’ basketball fell to 399,067 nationally, down from 412,407 the previous year, a decrease of 13,340 participants.

It was the lowest in 25 years, the federation reported, and the drop was largely attributable to Texas, which said that 10,636 fewer girls played basketball there, representing a 20% decrease in the state and accounting for the bulk of the national decrease.

Texas wouldn’t divulge its method of estimation, nor would it reveal how many of its 1,444 schools failed to provide data last year. But it said the procedure likely contributed to the apparent decrease.

“We think there has probably been a decline in girls’ basketball participation, but we’re not sure it’s as drastic as those numbers suggest,” said Jamey Harrison, deputy executive director of the University Interscholastic League, which administers athletic contests for the state’s public primary and secondary schools. “We believe our process of making estimates is better.”

Dr. Harrison also said the trend toward specialization may have played a role, with more students choosing to focus on fewer sports.

Although Texas declined to discuss its methodology, the other Top 5 five states described their approaches.

The California Interscholastic Federation said it inflates the number of participants reported for each sport based on the percentage of schools that don’t report. For example, if 80% of schools submitted basketball participation figures, the total would be increased by a flat percentage to approximate total participation. The figures aren’t weighted to reflect differences in school enrollment or previous athletic participation.

The Ohio and Illinois high-school athletic associations said they take the data they receive, calculate the average squad size for each sport and multiply the number of missing schools by the averages to approximate their figures.

The New York State Public High School Athletic Association said it hasn’t used estimates in any of the past four years. It reports only the numbers it receives, and last year 100% of its member schools provided data.

A final wrinkle in the participation survey is that it doesn’t represent the number of student athletes. An athlete who plays four different sports will be counted in each one—making a single student count as four participants.

Because of that, even if participation did fall, it wouldn’t necessarily mean fewer kids played sports. But there is evidence that some sports have lost players, even if the aggregated data are less than precise.

“Football is noticeably down,” said Tim Stried, director of communications for the Ohio High School Athletic Association. “We have eight schools in Ohio playing eight-man football. That’s a new phenomenon.”

More than a million boys compete on traditional 11-player teams in the U.S., making it the second largest high-school sport behind outdoor track and field. But nationally, 11-player football participation was down 3% over the previous year, according to the survey, and Ohio reported a decrease of 7%, which Mr. Stried believes is accurate.

“We never had any eight-man teams in the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s,” he said. “Maybe seven or eight years ago, a couple of schools dropped down to play eight-man. Now, it’s up to eight schools.”

And that, he said, is real data.

Write to Jo Craven McGinty at Jo.McGinty@wsj.com
description: A long-running survey of U.S. high-school sports participation made headlines this year by reporting that participation was down for the first time in three decades. There’s some reason for skepticism.
